summary: I may be thick but I still don't get the dynamic of the purple wedding. Why smuggle the poison in Sansa's hair net? Couldn't...
question: I may be thick but I still don't get the dynamic of the purple wedding. Why smuggle the poison in Sansa's hair net? Couldn't Olenna had brought it herself, it's not like guards were going to search her. I understand Littlefinger wanted to implicate Sansa so she would feel isolated but I don't get why the Tyrells went along with this unnecessarily complicated plan involving one person who isn't aware of it and might therefore inadvertently ruin everything (say she is sick and leaves the feast...)
answer:
It’s less about being searched by the guards than it is about being observed by spies. Until the moment Olenna took the poison from Sansa’s hairnet, the Tyrells had done nothing in King’s Landing that would stand up as evidence that they were involved in killing Joffrey. All the actual arrangements were made out of town. Littlefinger handled the procurement of the poison. There was nothing for Varys’ spies to actually observe, much less report on. Even that first meeting with Sansa (the content of which Olenna was careful to conceal from Varys) only establishes their motive for murder. And when it came to Joffrey, who didn’t have motive?

Poisoning Joffrey at the wedding also fits Tyrell goals best. Margaery was legally married to Joffrey thanks to the ceremony, but was never alone with him and he never had the opportunity to hurt her. The DIY attitude to putting poison in Joffrey’s cup meant that the Tyrells could be sure that it went into Joffrey’s cup (not some random’s, at this crowded feast) and that he’d drink it (rather than a food taster).

As for being able to rely on Sansa’s actions, attendance at this feast is an absolute political necessity. ‘A bit sick’ is not a good enough excuse for absence; even after Tyrion’s ugly run-in with Joffrey, he only suggests that he and Sansa leave the feast long enough for him to change his doublet. Sansa was always going to wear the hairnet, too.

“It’s very lovely,” Sansa said, thinking, It is a ship I need, not a net for my hair.

“Lovelier than you know, sweet child. It’s magic, you see. It’s justice you hold. It’s vengeance for your father.” Dontos leaned close and kissed her again. “It’s home.”

- Sansa VIII, ACoK

How could she not wear the hairnet, under the circumstances?

Overall, the plan meets the Tyrells’ foremost needs from an assassination: Margaery crowned queen without Joffrey getting the chance to hurt her, and no means for Lannister spies/Varys to discover their plot in advance. Whatever they felt about Sansa’s involvement, it was a risk they were willing to take.

And please don’t call yourself thick when asking me questions!

tags: it's quite clear that people are so dismissive of it partly because they see sansa and feminine women like her in general as inferior
and so sansa doesn't deserve jon
what she deserves is some guy a decade if not more older than her who shits on her constantly
why do you think tyrion rejecting penny isn't as criticized as sansa rejecting tyrion

why do you think that theon wanting sansa and not arya to marry him was never criticiced but sansa preferring loras to willas was
a song of ice and fire
i wrote this in reaction of multiple comments in reddit that rejected the notion from the OP that Jonsa could happen on the basis that Sansa
should be with some ugly dude because she liked handsome knights in season 1
even though it didn't concretely mention the ships
summary: People still reiterate the idea that just because Sansa wanted to be with some handsome knight when she was an 11 year old girl,...
body:
People still reiterate the idea that just because Sansa wanted to be with some handsome knight when she was an 11 year old girl, that she must pay by living the rest of her life with some ugly fellow who treated her terribly and that just doesn’t make sense to me. For starters, Sansa deserves no punishment in the first place for acting her age, and to continue, Sansa has been shown multiple times in later books that she has outgrown her narrow notions of ‘’beauty=goodness.’’. These notions aren’t things that indicates that Sansa is a bad person deserving to be punished, but rather shows that she is childish, but children are supposed to be childish in the first place. It would only be weird if she didn’t grow out of believing this kind of thing but she did. To continue, Tyrion and Theon get away with only wanting beautiful women with no criticism and even Jon gets away with not wanting ‘’some willowy creature who sits up in a tower, brushing her hair and waiting for some knight to rescue her, “. What’s really ironic about the last one is that people use Jon not wanting to be with a traditionally feminine woman as proof that him and Sansa will never be, yet Sansa wanting a handsome knight is proof that she won’t get one at the end. How does that make sense? Especially when Jon’s notions on traditional femininity are way more problematic especially if we consider his age. 

It seems to me that the reason as to why this is happening is because most of the audience for these books are adult heterosexual males, who relate to the idea of wanting to be with a beautiful woman, and adhere to the idea that traditional masculinity is superior to traditional femininity, so they are capable of not only understanding but relating to these feelings that these male POVs have in relation to women. However, on the other hand, Sansa is a young preteen girl, which is one of the demographics most mocked by adult heterosexual men partly due to their lack of ability to relate to these girls. Therefore what they want isn’t seen as important to them, whereas what characters like Jon or Tyrion wants is. Not to forget that Sansa desiring someone handsome is a problem to them because a lot of them had to deal with situations where they weren’t desired by a girl they liked and wrote it off as her being ‘’superficial’’ and so they want to punish Sansa for wanting someone conventionally attractive, yet the moment they or any of the male POVs do it, it’s perfectly comprehensible. In my opinion, this theory is yet another example on how ‘’audience sexism’’ affects the reception of the different characters in a story.

summary:
I feel like Sansa Stark fans are hypocrites. Here's why. 
They're all feminists. 
They say they like Sansa's storyline of...
body:
I feel like Sansa Stark fans are hypocrites. Here’s why.


  • They’re all feminists.
  • They say they like Sansa’s storyline of children and marriage. But then they post I’d rather live with my cat or dog.

They turn into Sansa antis.

reblog.comment:

  • They say they like Sansa’s storyline of children and marriage. But then they post I’d rather live with my cat or dog.

They turn into Sansa antis.

summary: I have a very strong desire to kick Harry Hardying in the nuts and I’m not quite sure why because we’ve seen very little of him...
body:
I have a very strong desire to kick Harry Hardying in the nuts and I’m not quite sure why because we’ve seen very little of him in canon. (Even before the teaser Alayne chapter on GRRM’s website which might get changed.)

Anyone else?

summary: Some instinct made her lift her hand and cup his cheek with her fingers. The room was too dark for her to see him, but she could...
body:
Some instinct made her lift her hand and cup his cheek with her fingers. The room was too dark for her to see him, but she could feel the stickiness of the blood, and a wetness that was not blood. “Little bird,” he said once more, his voice raw and harsh as steel on stone. Then he rose from the bed. Sansa heard clothes ripping, followed by the softer sound of retreating footsteps.

A Clash of Kings, Sansa VII

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: “There’s a cruel truth to it isn’t there? When there are two sisters so close in age, the more one becomes one thing the more...
caption:
“There’s a cruel truth to it isn’t there? When there are two sisters so close in age, the more one becomes one thing the more the other necessarily becomes the opposite and vice versa. It’s the way of things. If one is the queen, must be the source of honor and all that is good, the other necessarily becomes the focus of the most…creative malice. Evil sister.”

“No one says you’re evil.”

“Next to you i will always be evil. Feckless…lost…lesser thing.”

The Crown AU- Sansa as Elizabeth, Arya as Margret

summary: Bitch, I will fight for Sansa Stark and Jonsa wherever is the platform!!!  You can downvote me, you can harass me, you can...
caption:
Bitch, I will fight for Sansa Stark and Jonsa wherever is the platform!!! 

You can downvote me, you can harass me, you can insult me, but I will still be here standing still, giving my God Damn opinions. After season 8 premieres,it will be too easy for the so called experts to come out from their closets and bless us with their theories, but its now, during the long night, that the real magic happens.


“Bran thought about it. ‘Can a man still be brave if he’s afraid?’
'That is the only time a man can be brave,’ his father told him.”


― George R.R. Martin, A Game of Thrones


What can we do, we Jonsas unfortunately have too much Stark blood in our veins!!!! 


BTW - I am highly surprised by the level of the debates and inteligent conversation on QUORA. I am a not a huge fan of the set up of the website (its a questions and answers space and I much prefer the format of a forum) but I cant deny the quality of the discussions in that place. People there did their homework.

tags: dumb ass motherfuckers read ned's relief that his men found arya before cersei's and they still think sansa was 100% safe and protected
summary: I think people who blame Sansa for Mycah's death need to re-read the books, because Mycah was killed before Sansa ever spoke her...
question: I think people who blame Sansa for Mycah's death need to re-read the books, because Mycah was killed before Sansa ever spoke her testimony.
answer: Not to mention that Mycah’s murder like Lady’s death was all about the Cersei’s anger at precious Joffrey getting his ass kicked by a girl and a peasant. It’s like she took a page out of Tywin’s book on how to deal with humiliation. There’s literally nothing Sansa could do for Mycah, that’s on Ned the adult and Lord Paramount of the North. Antis would rather take Sansa’s words spoken in anger out of grief as proof that she’s responsible for everything that went wrong.

reblog.comment: Not to mention that Mycah’s murder like Lady’s death was all about the Cersei’s anger at precious Joffrey getting his ass kicked by a girl and a peasant.
